title: [Large-Scale] Preparing Integrated Science-Mathematics Curriculum via Collaborative Instructional Design: Focusing on Variable Control and Data Analysis

context.prior_knowledge: Fundamental grasp of secondary education curricula, basic mathematics pedagogy, and foundational concepts in science experiment design (variable control, measurement methods) and data analysis (graph interpretation, evidence evaluation)
context.additional_context: Strengthening competencies in designing science-integrated math curricula (solving mathematical problems using scientific inquiry processes: hypothesis-experiment-analysis-conclusion), and implementing collaborative learning activities in BYOD environments (collecting/sharing experimental data via mobile devices and utilizing scientific analysis tools).

learning_goals: Using a collaborative lesson design framework, learners create â‰¥2 lesson plans integrating scientific inquiry (observation, hypothesis, variable control) with math curricula (data analysis, graph interpretation, statistical reasoning).

Development of instructional materials to address math and science learning gaps for students with special needs by applying pre-teaching strategies (e.g., experimental design for identifying independent/dependent variables, utilization of measurement tools)

Learners design a 15-minute integrated science-math simulation (experimental data measurement, analysis, evidence-based conclusion) applying three core strategies of reform-based instruction (collaborative learning, inquiry-based activities, formative assessment) during a mid-term course (3 weeks) and can receive feedback achieving an average of 4 points or higher on a peer evaluation rubric (5-point scale, 5 items)
difficulty: Moderate - Standard complexity with some constraints
